DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Site discontinued retail/outside sales of anhydrous ammonia.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cremer Farm Center

1784 E. Howell Road,

Williamston, MI, 48895



Executive Summary

Risk Management Plan

Updated November, 2015



Cremer Farm Center is a family operated retail agricultural sales business, selling anhydrous ammonia, ammonium nitrate fertilizers and other agricultural products to local farms in area as well as using these same agricultural products at Cremer Farms, an active farm located at the same address.  The business was started in 1974; however the property was a family farm prior to the business incorporation.   Currently there 7 full time and one part time employees involved with the business.  Cremer Farm Center is located in a rural area in southeast Ingham County, Michigan with the closest non-family home located approximately 1/3 mile to the east of the site. 



Cremer has one 18,000 gallon anhydrous ammonia storage tank that has been on the property since 1967, a 100 ton ammonium nitrate 28% liquid fertilizer storage tank and three 1100 above ground diesel fuel storage tanks.  The liquid fertilizer tank and the diesel tank farm each have secondary containment.  There are also approximately 10-12 anhydrous ammonia nurse tanks stored at the business. These are usually stored empty and filled just prior to use. 



Cremer Farm Center has an Emergency Response Plan that has been in place since 2000.  It has been amended periodically as needed. There is currently one owner who also works on the farm and is the Emergency Response Coordinator responsible for all activities at Cremer Farm Center and Cremer Farms.   The business operation has a good safety record and regularly communicates with employees and local emergency response personnel on safety issues.   



The only chemical related accident that has happened in the past 10 years resulted from an attempted theft of anhydrous ammonia from one of the nurse tanks in June of 2010.  It is believed that a valve connecting a hose was cracked during the theft attempt allowing 1900 pounds o

f anhydrous ammonia to escape once the nurse tank was moved in route to field application of the fertilizer.  The entire incident was investigated by emergency response personnel and law enforcement officials. Because there was no off site property damage or injuries related to this release, it was not reported in the Five Year Accident History of our RMP.  No incidents have occurred in the past five years. 



Cremer Farm Center discussed options to improve security on the property with law enforcement officials and installed security measures including lighting to help with theft prevention.  It has also discussed the theft issue with employees to raise their awareness.  As part of the release investigation, Cremer Farm Services also filed a Tier II Report with the State and the Local Emergency Planning Committees and continues to file a Tier II report annually.
